children.name: the past
children.definition: /ðə ˈpɑːstǁ-ˈpæst/  the time that existed before the present time:

children.name: quá khứ
examples: ▪ My grandfather enjoys talking about the past.
▪ There were several horse-drawn carriages, as a nostalgic reminder of the past.

children.name: in the pastduring the time before now
examples: ▪ I decided to ask Anna, as she had always been very helpful in the past.
▪ In the past, doctors seemed to have more time for their patients than they do today.

children.name: the distant pasta long time before the present
examples: ▪ The programme describes events which took place in the distant past, towards the end of the last ice-age.

children.name: the recent pastnot a long time before the present
examples: ▪ It’s hard to see events from the very recent past in their proper historical perspective.

children.name: a thing of the pastsomething that used to happen or exist, but does not any more
examples: ▪ For many people, a relaxing weekend has become a thing of the past.

children.name: past mistakes
examples: ▪ Our goal was to learn from our past mistakes and to use the lessons on this project.

children.name: past
children.definition: /pɑːstǁpæst/  past events, experiences etc happened before now:

children.name: trong quá khứ
examples: ▪ He’s learned a lot from his past experience.
▪ Judging by her past performance, I’d say Rowena will do very well.
▪ Groups have put a lot into past projects, and have always seen an excellent result.

children.name: the past 10 years/2weeks etcthe 10 years, 2 weeks etc before now : 10 năm qua
examples: ▪ The past few months have been very difficult for Mary.
▪ For the past two weeks, I’ve been doing my boss’s job while she’s away on business.

children.name: ▪ the enormous changes of the past 30 years
happening over a period of time up to the present
recently
children.definition: /ˈriːsəntli/  use this to say that something has been happening for a fewweeksormonths, and it is still happening now :
examples: ▪ Her school work has been much better recently.
▪ I haven’t been feeling well recently.

children.name: just recently
examples: ▪ Just recently I’ve been thinking about changing my job.

children.name: more recently
examples: ▪ More recently, banks have offered customers the opportunity to change to PC or telephone banking.

children.name: lately
children.definition: /ˈleɪtli/  in the recent past until now, especiallyduringtheweeksordaysclosest to now:

children.name: gần đây
examples: ▪ The company went through a bad time last year, but lately things have been improving.
▪ I’ve been really busy lately, so I haven’t been out much.
▪ I don’t know what’s come over Angela lately -- she’s so moody.

children.name: in the last few weeks
children.definition: in the last/past few weeks/months etc/ɪn ðə ˌlɑːst, ˌpɑːst fjuː ˈwiːksǁ-ˌlæst, ˌpæst-/  during the weeks or months closest to now:
examples: ▪ Things have changed quite dramatically in the past few months.
▪ I’ve been thinking about Kevin a lot in the last few days. I wonder how he’s getting on?
▪ In the past few years, 30,000 of these high-rise housing units have been torn down.

children.name: in recent weeks
children.definition: /months etc/ɪn ˌriːsənt ˈwiːks/ formalduring the weeks or months closest to now - used especially in news reports :

children.name: vài tuần , tháng gần đây
examples: ▪ In recent months there have been rumors of at least two attempted coups.
▪ Illicit drug use - notably marijuana - has been increasing in recent years, especially among the young.

children.name: all the things that have happened in the past
sb’s/st’s past
children.definition: somebody’s/something’s past/ somebodyˈs/somethingˈs ˈpɑːstǁ-ˈpæst/  all the things that have happened to someone in the past:
examples: ▪ Greg didn’t like to talk about his past,
▪ The newspapers had been investigating the President’s past, hoping to find some scandal.
▪ The elegant buildings on the sea front give us a glimpse of Brighton’s more glorious past.

children.name: history
children.definition: /ˈhɪstəri/  all the things that have happened in the past, especially to a country, a town, or an organization:

children.name: the history of something/something’s history
examples: ▪ India has been invaded several times in its history.

children.name: ▪ a book about the history of the United Nations
record
children.definition: /ˈrekɔːdǁ-ərd/  all the things that a person, organization, country etc has done in the past, especially when talking abouthowgoodorbadthey are:
examples: hồ sơ
a good/bad/poor etc record
▪ As an employee, his record is outstanding.
▪ The US had serious concerns over the country’s poor human rights record.
record of
▪ The department has a long record of high achievement.
record on
▪ The industry’s record on conservation is not very impressive.
track recorda record that shows how experienced or skilful a person or organization is : hồ sơ thành tích
▪ HMA has a great track record of managing hospitals.

children.name: before
children.definition: /bɪˈfɔːʳ/  before now or before the time you are talking about:trước
examples: ▪ I had never seen such an ugly baby before.
Tôi chưa bao giờ thấy một đứa trẻ nào xấu như vậy trước đó
▪ Wendell had never been on a plane before.
Wendell chưa bao giờ đi máy bay trước đó
the day/week/year etc before: ngày / tuần,/ năm... trước
▪ Sheila and I became friends in 1995, although we had actually met several years before.
Sheila và tôi trở thành bạn bè với nhau vào 1995 mặc dụ chúng tôi đã gặp nhau vài năm trước đó

children.name: ago
children.definition: /əˈgəʊ/
examples: five minutes/two weeks/20 years etc agofive minutes, two weeks, twenty years etc before now:
trước ( khoảng bao lâu thời gian )
▪ George went out half an hour ago. Can I have him call you back?
George ra ngoài một giờ trước đó. Tôi có thể bảo anh ấy gọi lại cho anh được không?
▪ Lucy’s aunt died a few months ago.
Dì của Lucy mất vài tháng trước
a long time ago: một khoảng thời gian dài trước đó
▪ ‘When did you live in Germany?’ ‘Oh, it was a long time ago.’
"Bạn sống ở Đức lúc nào? " à, một khoảng thời gian dài trước đó"
ages agospoken a very long time ago:cách đây lâu rồi
▪ Pauline wrote to me once, but that was ages ago.
Pauline từng viết thư cho tôi một lần, nhưng là rất là lâu trước đó

children.name: previously
children.definition: /ˈpriːviəsli/  before a time or event in thepast:

children.name: trước đó ( trước một mốc thời gian trong quá khứ )
examples: ▪ Hastings previously worked for a software company in Richmond.

children.name: Hastings trước đó đã làm việc cho một công ty phần mềm ở Richmond
examples: ▪ The bombing is being blamed on a previously unknown group of terrorists.

children.name: Cuộc đánh bom được quy cho là do một tổ chức khủng bố vô danh
examples: two days/three weeks/six months etc previously:

children.name: khoảng thời gian bao lâu trước đó
examples: ▪ She had met Atwood at a conference a few weeks previously.

children.name: Cô ấy đã gặp Atwood tại cuộc hội thảo vài tuần trước đó
earlier
children.definition: /ˈɜːʳliəʳ/  at some time, date, year etcbeforenoworbeforethetimeyou aretalkingabout:

children.name: lúc trước , trước đó
examples: ▪ Didn’t I give you the key earlier?
Tôi đã đưa anh cái chìa khóa trước đó rồi mà?

children.name: earlier in the day/year etc: trước (trong ngày/năm/ thời gian)
examples: ▪ I saw Barbara earlier in the day - she looked pretty upset.

children.name: tôi gặp Barbara trước đó trong ngày, cô ấy trông rất thất vọng
examples: 20 years earlier/10 minutes earlier/moments earlier etc:

children.name: trước/sớm hơn 20 năm/10 phút/ thời gian bao lâu
examples: ▪ Three years earlier, Miller had been happily married, with a good job.

children.name: 3 năm trước, Miller đã kết hôn và có 1 công việc tốt
formerly
children.definition: /ˈfɔːʳməʳli/ formalduring a period in the past but not now:

children.name: trước đây ( trong suốt một khoảng thời gian trong quá khứ )
examples: ▪ Milligan, 43, was formerly a deputy foreign minister.

children.name: Milligan, 43, trước đó là bộ trưởng ngoại giao
examples: ▪ Peru was formerly ruled by the Spanish.

children.name: Peru trước kia được điều hành bởi người Tây Ban Nha
examples: ▪ Watkins was formerly editor of the Express, a local weekly newspaper.
Watkins trước đó là nhà biên tập cho tờ báo địa phương Express.

children.name: sb or st existed before or you had before
previous
children.definition: /ˈpriːviəs/  the previous person or thing is the one that existed just beforenowor beforethe time you are talking about:

children.name: trước
examples: ▪ The car’s previous owner didn’t take very good care of it.

children.name: Chủ trước của chiếc xe đã không chăm sóc nó kĩ lưỡng
examples: ▪ Please ignore my previous instructions.

children.name: Đừng bỏ qua lời chỉ dẫn lúc trước của tôi
last
children.definition: /lɑːstǁlæst/  the last thing or person is the one that you had just before now, or the one that existed just before now:

children.name: cuối cùng, trước đó ( liền kề với cái/ người hiện tại )
examples: ▪ The last apartment we lived in was much smaller than this one.
Căn hộ trước đó chúng tôi sống thì nhỏ hơn nhiều so với căn này.
▪ Beth broke up with her last boyfriend because he drank too much.

children.name: Beth chia tay bạn trai trước đó của cô ấy bởi vì anh ta uống rượu quá nhiều
ex-
children.definition: /eks/ ex-wife/ex-boyfriend/ex-soldier etc : someone who used to be someone’s wife, used to be a soldier etc, but is not any more:

children.name: trước, cũ, cựu ( đã từng )
examples: ▪ Her dad’s an ex-policeman.

children.name: Bố cô ấy là một cựu cảnh sát
examples: ▪ Lydia is still friends with her ex-husband.

children.name: Lydia vẫn là bạn với chồng cũ của cô ấy
old
children.definition: /əʊld/ somebody’s old job/car/girlfriend/boss etcthe job, car etc that someone had before the one they have now:

children.name: cũ
examples: ▪ The new stadium is much bigger than the old one.
▪ I saw Phil with one of my old girlfriends.
▪ We all liked the old teacher better.

children.name: former
children.definition: /ˈfɔːʳməʳ/ formaluse this especially to talk aboutsomeonewho used to have a particular job or position but does not any more:

children.name: nguyên , cố, trước, cựu
examples: ▪ Her former husband now lives in Houston.

children.name: Chồng cũ của cô ấy giờ sống ở Houston
examples: ▪ Weinberger was an advisor to former president Ronald Reagan.

children.name: Weinberger từng là cố vấn của cựu tổng thống Ronald Reagan
the one before
children.definition: /ðə ˌwʌn bɪˈfɔːʳ/  the person or thing that existed before the one youhavejustmentioned:

children.name: người/ vật trước đó ( trước người/ vật mà bạn đã đề cập )
examples: ▪ I didn’t enjoy Spielberg’s last film but I thought the one before was all right.

children.name: Tôi không thích bộ phim mới nhất của Spielberg nhưng tôi nghĩ cái bộ phim trước đó rất ổn
examples: ▪ Each year, the convention is a little larger than the one before.

children.name: Mỗi năm, quy ước lại nhiều hơn cái trước đó
predecessor
children.definition: /ˈpriːdɪsesəʳ, ˈpriːdəsesəʳǁˈpre-/ formalsomeone’s predecessor is the person who had the same job before them:

children.name: người tiền nhiệm
examples: ▪ Vandenberg has been a more active director than his predecessor.

children.name: Vandenberg đã là một giám độc có năng lực hơn so với người tiền nhiệm
examples: ▪ Sally’s predecessor had warned her about Nick, one of the company vice-presidents.

children.name: Những người đi trước đã cảnh báo Sally về Nick, anh ta là một trong những phó chủ tịch của công ty
precursor
children.definition: /prɪˈkɜːʳsəʳ/ formalsomeone whoseideasorstyleare later used by anothermorefamousperson, or anorganization,movementormachinethat later develops into one that is more important:

children.name: tiền thân, người đi trước, tổ tiên, nguyên mẫu đầu tiên
examples: precursor of/to:
▪ The abacus was the precursor of the modern electronic calculator.

children.name: Bàn tính chính là nguyên mẫu đầu tiên của máy tính điện tử
examples: ▪ The Office of Strategic Services was the precursor of the CIA.

children.name: Văn phòng dịch vụ chiến lược chính là tiền thân của CIA
forerunner
children.definition: /ˈfɔːˌrʌnəʳ/  the first person, organization, machine etc that existed before the one that exists now and that the one that exists now is based on:nguyên mẫu

children.name: forerunner of: nguyên mẫu của (cái gì)
examples: ▪ The P-50 is a forerunner of today’s supersonic jet.

children.name: P-50 chính là nguyên mẫu của máy bay siêu âm ngày nay
examples: ▪ Hansen played in the American Basketball League, a forerunner of the NBA.

children.name: Hansen từng chơi trong Liên đoàn bóng rổ Mỹ, tiền thân của NBA
when st happened or was true in the past but not now
used to
children.definition: /ˈjuːst tuː/  if someone or something used to do something, they did it for a period of time in the past, or they did it regularly in the past, but they do not do it now:
examples: ▪ ‘Do you smoke?’ ‘No, but I used to.’
used to do something
▪ We used to live in Glasgow when I was young.
there used to be
▪ Thirty years ago, there used to be a market in the town.
never used to
▪ It never used to rain as much as this.
didn’t use to do somethingspoken
▪ I was surprised to see her driving - she didn’t use to.
used not to do somethingformal
▪ He used not to be so critical of other people’s behaviour.

children.name: once/at one time
children.definition: /wʌns, ət ˌwʌn ˈtaɪm/  during a period of time in the past but not now - use this when it is not important to say exactly when this period was:

children.name: đã có lần, đã có thời
examples: ▪ Apparently he once worked for the FBI.
▪ It is a big city now, but at one time the population was only 50,000.

children.name: ▪ a sports car once owned by Paul McCartney
(back) then/at that time
children.definition: /(bæk) ˈðen, ət ðæt ˌtaɪm/  during a particular period of time in the past - use this when you are comparing that period with the present:

children.name: tại thời điểm đó
examples: ▪ I was a student in the 1950s, and things were very different then.
▪ At that time most married women stayed at home.

children.name: in the past
children.definition: /ɪn ðə ˈpɑːstǁ-ˈpæst/  use this to talk about asituationthat existed before the present time but does not exist now:

children.name: trong quá khứ, ngày xưa, hồi xưa
examples: ▪ In the past, most children didn’t go to school at all.
▪ Women were not allowed to vote or own property in the past.

children.name: in those days/in the old days
children.definition: /ɪn ˈðəʊz ˌdeɪz, ɪn ði ˈəʊld ˌdeɪz/  use this to talk about a long time ago inyourlife, or in yourparents’ orgrandparents’ lives, when things were different:

children.name: ngày đó, thời đó
examples: ▪ My great grandfather earned £5 a week, which was a lot of money in those days.
▪ In the old days there was no bridge over the river, and we crossed it by boat.

children.name: in the good old daysat a time when you think that things werebetterthan now : vào những ngày vàng son đó
examples: ▪ In the good old days people showed more respect to the older generation.

children.name: in the olden days
children.definition: /ɪn ði ˈəʊldn ˌdeɪz/  at a timebefore you were born, especially hundreds of years ago:

children.name: ngày xưa ( khi chưa sinh ra )
examples: ▪ The children all wanted to know what life was like in the olden days.

children.name: formerly
children.definition: /ˈfɔːʳməʳli/  written in the past, before the presentsituationexisted:

children.name: trước đây
examples: ▪ The local school was formerly a hospital.
▪ Peru was formerly ruled by the Spanish.

children.name: to try to do things as they were done in the past
go back
children.definition: /ˌgəʊ ˈbæk/  to return to anearliertime in your life, so that you can experience something again or change something that you did then - use this to say that youwishyou could do this:
examples: trở lại , trở về
go back to
▪ I wish I could go back to my school days.
▪ Wouldn’t it be nice if we could go back to the days when life was slower than it is today.
you can’t go back
▪ It’s no use having regrets. You can’t go back!

children.name: put/turn the clock back
children.definition: /ˌpʊt, ˌtɜːʳn ðə ˈklɒk ˌbækǁ-ˈklɑːk-/  to live part of your life again, so that you could do something in adifferentway, orexperiencesomething again:
examples: quay ngược thời gian , quay ngược đồng hồ
▪ If I could turn the clock back, I don’t think I’d study law again.put/turn the clock back to
▪ It would be nice to put the clock back to the years when Mum and Dad were still alive.

children.name: live in the past
children.definition: /ˌlɪv ɪn ðə ˈpɑːstǁ-ˈpæst/  to try tobehaveorliveas you did at some time in the past, usually because you do not like your present situation or you are unhappy that things have changed:

children.name: sống theo, trong quá khứ
examples: ▪ It’s no good living in the past. You have to get on with your life.
▪ As people get older, they often tend to live in the past.

children.name: recently
children.definition: /ˈriːsəntli/  if somethinghappenedrecently, it happened a short time before now, especially a fewdaysorweeksago:
examples: gần đây, mới đây
▪ The President has recently returned from a five day tour of South America.
only recently
▪ a new species of plant that was only recently discovered in southern Brazil
until recently : cho đến gần đây
▪ He lived in Boston until quite recently.
▪ Until recently, commercial fishermen had been allowed to shoot sea lions if they tried to steal their catch.
very recently :
▪ ‘When did she go back to Italy?’ ‘Oh, very recently - just a couple of days ago.’
as recently asused when something happenedsurprisinglyrecently : vừa mới đây thôi
▪ As recently as the mid sixties, Nelson Rockefeller was considered unsuitable for the presidency because he had once been divorced.
recently discovered/completed/built etc
▪ a recently published textbook
▪ the recently industrialized countries of Southeast Asia

children.name: not long ago
children.definition: /nɒt ˌlɒŋ əˈgəʊǁ-ˌlɔːŋ-/  in the recent past:
examples: ko lâu trước đây
▪ Not long ago, computers were crude, unreliable machines, used by only a few experts.
▪ Not long ago I asked a friend what her children gave her for her birthday. ‘Peace,’ she said. ‘They went out for the day.’
not so long ago
▪ There was a time not so long ago when everyone felt confident about investing in property.

children.name: a short time ago
children.definition: /ə ˌʃɔːʳt ˈtaɪm əˌgəʊ/  very recently:

children.name: 1 thời gian ngắn trước đây
examples: ▪ So what is the government’s reaction to this news? A short time ago our political correspondent Jon Lander spoke to the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook.
▪ The red wolf survived until a short time ago in east Texas, but is now believed extinct in the wild.

children.name: only/just a short time ago
examples: ▪ Seeing the tramp, Thomas remembered how he himself had been poor only a short time ago.

children.name: newly
children.definition: /ˈnjuːliǁˈnuːli/ newly formed/created/appointed/married etcformed, married etc very recently, especially during the last few days or weeks:

children.name: mới , gần đây
examples: ▪ A newly married couple have moved into the house next door.
▪ The group meets regularly in the newly built Chinese community center.
▪ Mr Chandler is now director of the company’s newly formed publishing division.

children.name: freshly
children.definition: /ˈfreʃli/ freshly cut/cooked/made/painted etccut, cooked etc a very short time ago, especially during the last few minutes or hours:

children.name: vừa mới ( cắt, nấu, làm , sơn ...)
examples: ▪ There’s a pot of freshly made coffee on the kitchen table.
▪ Add one clove of freshly crushed garlic.
▪ Someone had placed a bunch of freshly cut roses on her desk.
▪ At the beginning of term the school looked bright and clean with its freshly painted walls and polished floors.

children.name: the other day
children.definition: /ði ˌʌðəʳ ˈdeɪ/ spokenuse this to say that something happened or you did something recently:

children.name: mới hôm nào, mới hôm nọ
examples: ▪ I met Lucy the other day outside Budgens.
▪ Well, did my dad tell you what happened to me in the car the other day?

children.name: just the other day
examples: ▪ I can’t believe this weather - it was freezing just the other day!

children.name: a short/little while ago
children.definition: /ə ˌʃɔːʳt, ˌlɪtl ˈwaɪl əˌgəʊ/  a short time ago, usuallynot more than a few hours:
examples: lúc nãy, cách đây ít lâu
▪ ‘Is there a Mrs Lambert staying at the hotel?’ ‘Yes, she checked in a short while ago.’
just a short/little while ago
▪ Bobby’s attorney gave me a call just a little while ago, to talk about the terms of the will.

children.name: a little while back
children.definition: /ə ˌlɪtl waɪl ˈbæk/ informalfairly recently, usually a fewweeksormonthsago:

children.name: mới , vừa mới ( vài tuần, tháng )
examples: ▪ I broke my leg a little while back when I fell off a horse.

children.name: on one occasion in the past
once
children.definition: /wʌns/

children.name: có lúc, có lần
examples: ▪ She once called me a liar - I’ve never forgiven her.
▪ Once, when I was a little boy, I found a gold watch on the beach.

children.name: one time
children.definition: /ˈwʌn ˌtaɪm/ informalon one occasion in the past:

children.name: có lần
examples: ▪ One time we went out fishing on the lake at night.
▪ Aileen came round to tea one time, and we did our homework together.

children.name: one day/morning/afternoon
children.definition: /wʌn ˈdeɪ, ˈmɔːʳnɪŋ, ˌɑftəʳˈnuːnǁ-ˌæf-/  on a day, morning, or afternoon in the past - use this when it isnotimportantto say exactly which day it is:
examples: có hôm ...
▪ Then, one day he went away and never came back.
▪ I was having my breakfast one morning when the telephone rang.
▪ One day, when we had nothing else to do, we went for a swim in the river.

children.name: on one occasion
children.definition: /ɒn ˈwʌn əˌkeɪʒən/  something that happened on one occasion happened once in the past, but is oftentypicalof what usually happens:

children.name: có lần
examples: ▪ He drinks far too much. On one occasion I saw him drink a whole bottle of vodka.
▪ On one occasion I made the mistake of arriving at work late and my boss has never let me forget it.

children.name: at one stage
children.definition: /ət ˈwʌn ˌsteɪdʒ/  if a particularsituationexisted at one stage during a period in the past, it existed, butonlyat that time :

children.name: có giai đoạn
examples: ▪ It was a terrible winter. At one stage, we had to dig our way out of the house.
▪ At one stage during the competition, it looked as though our team might win.
▪ I went on a diet and at one stage I weighed only 71 kg.

children.name: at one point
children.definition: /ət ˈwʌn ˌpɔɪnt/  if something happened, especially somethinginterestingorimportant, at one point during an activity or period of time in the past, it happened then:

children.name: đã có lúc, đã có thời điểm
examples: ▪ At one point in the interview Gorbachev admitted he had made serious mistakes.
▪ ‘You play the piano very well,’ I remember Mrs Saito remarking at one point.

children.name: when st happened a short time ago
just
children.definition: /dʒʌst/

children.name: vừa mới
examples: ▪ Sorry, she just left for home. Can I take a message?
▪ The war had just ended, and the country’s economy was in ruins.
▪ You’ve had your hair cut, haven’t you? I’ve just noticed.
▪ I just heard the news! Congratulations!

children.name: only just
children.definition: /ˌəʊnli ˈdʒʌst◂/  especially British a very short time ago:

children.name: chỉ vừa mới
examples: ▪ It’s noon, and she’s only just got up.
▪ I’ve only just passed my driving test, so I’m still a little nervous.

children.name: a minute/second ago
children.definition: alsoa moment agoespecially British /ə ˈmɪnt, ˈsekənd əˌgəʊ, ə ˈməʊmənt əˌgəʊ/ spokena very short time ago - use this especially when a situation haschanged:
examples: ▪ She was here a minute ago.
▪ There was a phone call for you a second ago, but I didn’t know where you were.
▪ What did I do with my glasses? I had them in my hand a moment ago.

children.name: just now
children.definition: alsojustthisminuteBritish /ˌdʒʌst ˈnaʊ, ˌdʒʌst ðɪs ˈmɪnt/ spokena very short time ago - use this especially when you are answering someone who islooking forsomeoneelse:
examples: vừa mới
▪ ‘Have you seen Carl?’ ‘I just this minute hung up on him.’
▪ She just now left, so she should be home by six.
▪ Didn’t I just this minute tell you to tidy your room!
▪ Sandy was on the Internet just now, that’s why the phone was busy.

children.name: barely/hardly/scarcely
children.definition: barelyalsohardly/scarcelyBritish /ˈbeəʳli, ˈhɑːʳdli, ˈskeəʳsli/ spokenuse this to say that somethinghadjusthappenedwhen something elsehappened:

children.name: chỉ vừa mới
examples: ▪ I had scarcely opened the door when the dog came running in.
▪ She had barely slept 10 minutes before she was woken up again.
▪ The class had barely started when the fire bell rang.
▪ Hardly had King finished speaking when a shot was fired by someone in the crowd.

children.name: at a particular time in the past
then
children.definition: /ðen/

children.name: lúc đó
examples: ▪ She thought back over her early married life; everything had been so different then.
▪ They were living in the country then, on a farm.
▪ These days it’s OK for women to smoke in public, but then it was unheard of.

children.name: then and only thennot until that time
examples: ▪ Bob sat down and read the letter again slowly. Then and only then did it begin to sink in that Stella was really dead.

children.name: just thenat that exact moment
examples: ▪ I sat down at my desk and got out a pile of reports to read. Just then, the phone rang.

children.name: at that/the time
children.definition: /ət ˌðæt, ðə ˈtaɪm/  at a particular period of time in the past - use this especially when you are talking about what the situation was then ascomparedto the present time:

children.name: lúc đó
examples: ▪ At that time, he was married to a woman called Jody.
▪ I was offered a job in New York, but at the time I didn’t want to move so far away from my family.
▪ The accepted view at that time was that women should remain in the home and not go out to work.
▪ I can’t remember exactly what he said, but I do remember thinking it was very funny at the time.

children.name: in those days/back then
children.definition: /ɪn ˈðəʊz ˌdeɪz, ˌbæk ˈðen/  at that time in the past - use this especially when you arecomparinglife in the past with life in the present:

children.name: hồi đó
examples: ▪ We used to get paid £2 a week. That was a lot of money in those days.
▪ In those days there was no proper road, just an old stony track through the woods.
▪ Back then, most people left school at fourteen and started work.
▪ I remember thinking, back then, that I would never get married.

children.name: at that point
children.definition: /ət ˌðæt ˈpɔɪnt/  at thatexacttime during a past event or situation:

children.name: tại thời điểm đó
examples: ▪ Miles got up to make his speech, and at that point several of the guests quietly slipped out of the room.
▪ I thought he was dead. At that point, everything seemed hopeless.

children.name: at that moment
children.definition: /ət ˌðæt ˈməʊmənt/  at theexacttime when something happened or when someone did something - use this whendescribingpast events ortellingstories:

children.name: thời điểm đó
examples: ▪ At that moment there was a knock on the door.
▪ Fortunately, Jorge appeared at that moment and was able to help us load things into the van.

children.name: just at that momentat that exact moment
examples: ▪ Just at that moment, the police arrived.

children.name: at that stage
children.definition: /ət ˌðæt ˈsteɪdʒ/ duringa particular period of time in the past, although things were going to change or develop later:

children.name: trong giai đoạn đó
examples: ▪ At that stage I lacked the experience to apply for a management post.
▪ At that stage in the inquiry, the police still hoped that Maria might be alive.

children.name: words for describing an event that has happened recently
recent
children.definition: /ˈriːsənt/  use this about something that happened recently, especially a few days or weeks ago.:

children.name: gần đây
examples: ▪ He hadn’t completely recovered from his recent illness.
▪ A recent report said that small amounts of alcohol are good for the health.
▪ The team returned to a heroes’ welcome after their recent success in the European Championships.

children.name: latest
children.definition: /ˈleɪtɪst, ˈleɪtəst/  someone’s latest book, record, film etc is the one produced most recently; someone’s latest action is the one that happened most recently:

children.name: mới nhất, gần đây nhất
examples: ▪ In her latest movie she plays an LA cop.
▪ The latest attempt to reach a peace settlement ended in failure.

children.name: the latestthe latest one
examples: ▪ This is the latest in a series of Mafia killings.

children.name: words for describing news or information that is recent
latest
children.definition: /ˈleɪtɪst, ˈleɪtəst/  the latest news, information etc is the most recent news, information etc:

children.name: mới nhất, gần đây nhất
examples: ▪ Tune into Radio 5 Live for the latest news and sport.
▪ For the latest information visit the German National Tourist Office website at htt//www.germany-tourism.de.
▪ The girls spent the evening catching up on the latest gossip.

children.name: the latestthe latest news
examples: ▪ Have you heard the latest? Nicky’s getting married.

children.name: up-to-date
children.definition: /ˌʌp tə ˈdeɪt◂/  up-to-date information is the most recent and correct information:

children.name: cập nhật
examples: ▪ Is this map up-to-date? It doesn’t seem to show the new road.
▪ Foreign embassies or consulates in the United States can provide up-to-date information on their countries.

children.name: up-to-the-minute
children.definition: /ˌʌp tə ðə ˈmɪnt◂/  up-to-the-minute news or information is the most recent news or information about something that is likely to change very quickly all the time:
examples: ▪ Visit www.sportsfanatic.com for up-to-the-minute results and sports news.
▪ A computer link with Wall Street gives traders up-to-the-minute market data worldwide.

children.name: once upon a time
children.definition: ngày xửa ngày xưa
examples: once upon a time
used at the beginning of children's stories to mean 'a long time ago'
_Once upon a time there was a beautiful young princess with long golden hair.
once upon a time
used in a slightly literary way when referring to something that happened in
the past, especially when showing that you feel sorry that it no longer happens
_Once upon a time people knew the difference between
right and wrong, but nowadays nobody seems to care.
